That's a great approach! Gathering items that remind you of your grandmother and organizing them in a way that feels personal to you is a wonderful way to start creating your memory box. Adding photos and mementos from other family members can make it an even more special and collaborative effort.

Remember, there's no right or wrong way to create a memory box. It's a personal and intimate process, and it's okay to take your time and experiment with different arrangements and layouts until it feels just right.

As you gather items, you might consider asking yourself questions like:

* What are the most meaningful items to me?
* What stories do these items tell about my grandmother?
* How can I arrange these items in a way that feels visually appealing and easy to navigate?
* What kind of box or container feels right for this collection?

You might also consider involving other family members in the process, whether it's by asking them to contribute items or sharing your progress with them along the way. This can be a great way to spark conversations and share memories with loved ones.

Most importantly, remember to be patient and kind to yourself as you work on your memory box. It's a process that can be emotional and introspective, but it's also an opportunity to celebrate your grandmother's life and legacy.

If you have any questions or need any guidance along the way, feel free to reach out. I'm here to support you.
